Posts.Content: Well tomorrow is the big day. After dealing with the worry and stress I am actually ready for surgery. I hope it goes well and my recovery is as good as most of the people on this forum. RALP for Ralph. LOL, maybe thats a good sign! Thanks for all the support and feedback. Ralph

Posts.Content: RALP Jan 2, 2018 Just got bloodwork results back today. Undetectable!! I am thrilled. I see the Dr. Monday. I assume I will get regular PSA tests every few months now going forward. Good luck to everyone still going through the journey. I am satisfied with my choices and outcomes. Take care!

Posts.Title: RALP in 20 hours

Posts.Content: Update... I met with a surgeon this week. He has done 1500 prostate surgeries and I am comfortable with him. I have surgery scheduled Jan 2. He said he always waits 8 weeks minimum after biopsy to allow everything to heal up and allow the best odds for nerve sparing surgery. I am still meeting with the Univ of Chicago for a second opinion on pathology on Nov. 29. While I am comfortable with the surgeon I have chosen, I see no harm in a second opinion;. Thanks for the feedback.
Posts.Title: deciphering test results and figuring out treatment path

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. I have read many posts and am impressed with the knowledge level of this group. I apologize for all the data below, I didn't know what data might be valuable to the members of this group. I could use some help with what my results actually mean and feedback on my plan. I appreciate your help! I was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer 4 days ago. My local urologist said I had Gleason 6 and 7 cancer and that the prostate needed removal soon. He said I could have surgery or robotic surgery. He said Robotic surgery had no better results but some people liked the newest technology. He said I was not a good candidate for radiation because of my young ((58 LOL)) age. I have an appointment 1n 20 days for a second opinion on treatment from University of Chicago Cancer center. I feel like a team approach at a hospital well skilled in this is the best path. My PSA record 10/2012=3.89, 4/2013=3.51, 5/2015=5.4, 11/2015 = 4.7, 11/2016 = 6.1, 5/2017= 6.4, 8/2017 = 6.9 Had a 3T Color MRI done Feb 2017. Came back clean. No tumors, no issues. But PSA kept rising. Had a 12 needle random biopsy 0 11/01/2017: Pathologic Diagnosis : A: Prostate, right apex, core biopsy: - A tiny focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3=6, occupying less than 5% of core volume B-D: Prostate, sites as specified below, core biopsies: - Benign prostatic parenchyma, negative for carcinoma E: Prostate, left lateral, core biopsy: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3 = 6, involving three of three cores and occupying approximately 10% of total core volume F: Prostate, left base, core biopsy: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+4 = 7, involving two of two cores and occupying approximately 45% of total core volume TUMOR Histologic Type: Adenocarcinoma (acinar, not other wise specified) Histologic Grade Gleason Pattern: Gleason pattern Primary (Predominant) Pattern: Grade 3 Secondary (Worst Remaining) Pattern: Grade 4 Total Gleason Score: 7 Tumor Quantitation Number of Cores Positive: 6 Total Number of Cores: 12 Tumor Quantitation: Proportion (%) of prostatic tissue involved by tumor: Approximately 5% Proportion (%) of Prostatic Tissue Involved by Tumor for Core with the Greatest Amount of Tumor: Approximately 45 % ACCESSORY FINDINGS Lymph-Vascular Invasion: Not identified Perineural Invasion: Not identified
Posts.Title: deciphering test results and figuring out treatment path

Posts.Content: You are correct that I am not 100% . My understanding is that I am meeting a team to evaluate my pathology ang look at all options. I will verify this. I am quite confused on radiation as both urologists I have met say it is a poor option for someone my age. I will be sure to meet with a radiologist though. Thank you.
Posts.Title: deciphering test results and figuring out treatment path

Posts.Content: You are correct that I am not 100% . My understanding is that I am meeting a team to evaluate my pathology ang look at all options. I will verify this. I am quite confused on radiation as both urologists I have met say it is a poor option for someone my age. I will be sure to meet with a radiologist though. Thank you.

Posts.Title: deciphering test results and figuring out treatment path

Posts.Content: It feels like when your body wakes you up and you have to pee. Some pressure. I have learned to stand up and move around and it seems to go away..
Posts.Signature: A: Prostate, right apex, biopsy:A tiny focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3=6, occupying less than 5% of core volume B-D: Prostate, sites as specified below, core biopsies: Benign prostatic parenchyma, negative for carcinoma E: Prostate, left lateral, core biopsy: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3 = 6, involving three of three cores and occupying appx 10% of total core volume F: Prostate, left base, core biopsy: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+4 = 7, involving two of two cores and occupying appx 45% of total core volume MRI Feb 2017 = clear PSA current 6.9 Biopsy Nov. 2017 Adenocarcinoma Primary (Predominant) Pattern: Grade 3 Secondary (Worst Remaining) Pattern: Grade 4 Total Gleason Score: 7 Number of Cores Positive: 6 Tumor Quantitation: Appx 5% Proportion of Prostatic Tissue Involved by Tumor for Core with the Greatest Amount of Tumor: Approximately 45 %
Posts.Title: RALP complete / Onto the other side.

Posts.Content: Well yesterday and surgery came and went. The doctor and team at St. Lukes was great. Surgery itself was a little longer than the doctor thought it would go. The right side went smooth but the tumor was very close to the nerve on the left side. He spent extra time on that side. Had to take about a millimeter of the nerve. I feel pretty good and came home this afternoon. Belly is a bit sore, but so far havent taken any thing stronger than a couple Tylenol. Worst part is feeling I have to pee, but obviously have a catheter in. We will see how the first night at home goes, but so far so good. Thanks for all the support and info. I felt like I knew what was coming at me Ralph

Posts.Title: RALP complete / Onto the other side.

Posts.Content: Good luck with the test. My personal experience was that the 3T color Doppler MRI came back with perfect results. No problem areas at all. My PSA went up again three months later. Then had the biopsy which found the cancer.

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI on Friday

Posts.Content: I met with my surgeon today, 6 days post RALP. Dr. Said I was healing nicely and removed the catheter. That was 5 hours ago, as so far still dry. I have urinated twice also during that time. I am encouraged so far. The last two days I walked 2 miles each day. Final pathology had no real surprises. Tumor was Gleason 3+4 =7. 30% of prostate was involved by tumor. Weight was 42.8 G. The Dr. shared with me that the surgery took about an hour longer than planned due to the tumor pressing up against the nerves on the left side. He said he spent a fair amount of time on this section but was able to save 70% of the left nerve. The right nerve was fine with normal margins. So now I try to get a handle on how how incontenance will effect me and start the 90 day countdown to the first PSA test. Thanks again for all the support. Ralph
Posts.Signature: A: Prostate, right apex, biopsy:A tiny focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3=6, occupying less than 5% of core volume B-D: Prostate, sites as specified below, core biopsies: Benign prostatic parenchyma, negative for carcinoma E: Prostate, left lateral, core biopsy: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3 = 6, involving three of three cores and occupying appx 10% of total core volume F: Prostate, left base, core biopsy: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+4 = 7, involving two of two cores and occupying appx 45% of total core volume MRI Feb 2017 = clear PSA current 6.9 Biopsy Nov. 2017 Adenocarcinoma Primary (Predominant) Pattern: Grade 3 Secondary (Worst Remaining) Pattern: Grade 4 Total Gleason Score: 7 Number of Cores Positive: 6 Tumor Quantitation: Appx 5% Proportion of Prostatic Tissue Involved by Tumor for Core with the Greatest Amount of Tumor: Approximately 45 %
Posts.Title: Surgical pathology / catheter removal

Posts.Content: If I end up wasting money on all the pads I bought, it will be the best money I have ever wasted. Dry overnight last night, and so far good today. But I am not overconfident, as someone said, everyone’s path is different. Strange Garyi, 7 weeks dry and then some leaks. I have never heard that happen before. Did a mile on the treadmill this morning, nice and slow. Don’t want to push it. Thanks guys.

Posts.Title: Surgical pathology / catheter removal

Posts.Content: 1. RALP 2. After extensive research and reading this forum, it offered the best long term expectations for my age. (59) 3. Surgery went well. One night in hospital. 6 days with catheter. Never took anything stronger than regular Tylenol. No continence issues at all. Some minor bleeding while urinating The first week after catheter removal. Back to work - Part time after 13 days. Feeling better every day. Good luck with your decision. You will find lots of great info here. Good luck..Ralph
